Tokyo-merge.sent: Tokyo (ˈtoʊkioʊ, Japanese: toːkʲoː), officially Tokyo Metropolis, is the capital city of Japan and one of its 47 prefectures.
The Greater Tokyo Area is the most populous metropolitan area in the world.
It is the seat of the Emperor of Japan and the Japanese government.
Tokyo is in the Kantō region on the southeastern side of the main island Honshu and includes the Izu Islands and Ogasawara Islands.

arg2.text: the southeastern side of the main island Honshu
arg2.dc_text: the southeastern side of the main island Honshu

arg2.text: the southeastern side of the main island Honshu
arg2.dc_text: the southeastern side of the main island Honshu

Tokyo-merge.sent: Formerly known as Edo, it has been the de facto seat of government since 1603 when Shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu made the city his headquarters.

arg3+.text: since Shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu made (the city)/Tokyo his headquarters

Tokyo-merge.sent: It officially became the capital after Emperor Meiji moved his seat to the city from the old capital of Kyoto in 1868; at that time Edo was renamed Tokyo.

arg3+.text: after Emperor Meiji moved his/(Emperor Meiji's) seat to (the city)/Tokyo
from the old capital of Kyoto

arg2.text: the old capital/(capital city of Japan)
arg2.dc_text: the old capital city of Japan

Tokyo-merge.sent: Tokyo Metropolis was formed in 1943 from the merger of the former Tokyo Prefecture (東京府 Tōkyō-fu) and the city of Tokyo (東京市 Tōkyō-shi).

arg2.text: the merger of the Tokyo Prefecture and the city of Tokyo
arg2.dc_text: the merger of the Tokyo Prefecture and the city of Tokyo

Tokyo-merge.sent: Tokyo is often referred to as a city, but is officially known and governed as a "metropolitan prefecture", which differs from and combines elements of a city and a prefecture, a characteristic unique to Tokyo.

The Tokyo metropolitan government administers the 23 Special Wards of Tokyo (each governed as an individual city), which cover the area that was the City of Tokyo before it merged and became the metropolitan prefecture in 1943.

arg1.text: each/(each [of] the 23 Special Wards of Tokyo)
arg1.dc_text: each [of] the 23 Special Wards of Tokyo

arg2.text: the area that was the City of Tokyo
arg2.dc_text: the area that was the City of Tokyo

Tokyo-merge.sent: The metropolitan government also administers 39 municipalities in the western part of the prefecture and the two outlying island chains.

arg3+.text: in the western part of (the prefecture)/Tokyo

arg2.text: (the two outlying island chains)/(the Izu Islands and the Ogasawara Islands)
arg2.dc_text: the Izu Islands and the Ogasawara Islands

Tokyo-merge.sent: The population of the special wards is over 9 million people, with the total population of the prefecture exceeding 13 million.

arg1.text: The population of (the special wards)/(the 23 Special Wards of Tokyo)
arg1.dc_text: The population of the 23 Special Wards of Tokyo

arg1.text: (the special wards)/(the 23 Special Wards of Tokyo)

Tokyo-merge.sent: The prefecture is part of the world's most populous metropolitan area with upwards of 37.8 million people and the world's largest urban agglomeration economy.

arg2.text: (the world's most populous metropolitan area)/(The Greater Tokyo Area)

arg1.text: (the world's most populous metropolitan area)/(The Greater Tokyo Area)

arg2.text: the world's largest urban agglomeration economy
arg2.dc_text: the world's largest urban agglomeration economy

Tokyo-merge.sent: In 2011, the city hosted 51 of the Fortune Global 500 companies, the highest number of any city in the world, at that time.

arg2.text: (the highest number)/(the highest number of Fortune Global 500 companies) of any city in the world
arg2.dc_text: the highest number of Fortune Global 500 companies of any city in the world

Tokyo-merge.sent: Tokyo ranked third (twice) in the International Financial Centres Development IndexEdit.

arg3+.text: in the International Financial Centres Development IndexEdit

Tokyo-merge.sent: The city is also home to various television networks such as Fuji TV, Tokyo MX, TV Tokyo, TV Asahi, Nippon Television, NHK and the Tokyo Broadcasting System.

Finnish-merge.sent: Finnish police reprimanded a man for traveling in a car boot to hide his meeting with Prime Minister Juha Sipila during a government crisis last summer, saying this was breach of the traffic code.

arg3+.text: for traveling in a car boot
for traveling in a car boot

Finnish-merge.sent: A police statement did not name the man in the boot, but in effect indicated the traveler was State Secretary Samuli Virtanen, who is also the deputy to Foreign Minister Timo Soini.

arg2.text: the deputy to Foreign Minister Timo Soini
arg2.dc_text: the deputy to Foreign Minister Timo Soini

Finnish-merge.sent: The meeting took place in June, a day after Virtanen’s co-ruling Finns party had elected anti-immigration hardliners as its new leaders.

arg2.text: a day after [the] Finns party had elected anti-immigration hardliners as its/(the Finns party's) new leaders
arg2.dc_text: a day after [the] Finns party had elected anti-immigration hardliners as the Finns party's new leaders

arg3+.text: as its/(the Finns party's) new leaders

Finnish-merge.sent: The government was close to collapse until a group of politicians, including Virtanen and Soini, in the following week walked out of the Finns party and announced they would form a new group.

arg2.text: they/(a group of politicians) would form (a new group)/(Blue Reform)
arg2.dc_text: a group of politicians would form Blue Reform

arg1.text: a group of politicians including Virtanen and Soini
arg1.dc_text: a group of politicians including Virtanen and Soini

arg2.text: they/(a group of politicians) would form (a new group)/(Blue Reform)
arg2.dc_text: a group of politicians would form Blue Reform

arg1.text: a group of politicians including Virtanen and Soini
arg1.dc_text: a group of politicians including Virtanen and Soini

Finnish-merge.sent: The Finns party was thrown out of the government and the new “Blue Reform” group kept its cabinet seat.
Virtanen has not commented on the case, but lawmaker Tiina Elovaara from Blue Reform said in a blog that Virtanen climbed into the boot to keep the meeting secret at a critical moment.

arg2.text: Virtanen/(Samuli Virtanen) climbed into the boot to keep the meeting secret at a critical moment
arg2.dc_text: Samuli Virtanen climbed into the boot to keep the meeting secret at a critical moment

arg3+.text: to keep the meeting secret at a critical moment

Finnish-merge.sent: “He avoided media attention when the situation was most serious, and the risk of leakage about the parliamentarians’ transition was too big,” Elovaara said.

arg3+.text: when the situation was most serious

arg1.text: the risk of leakage about the parliamentarians’ transition
arg1.dc_text: the risk of leakage about the parliamentarians’ transition

arg2.text: He/(Samuli Virtanen) avoided media attention when the situation was most serious, and the risk of leakage about the parliamentarians’ transition was too big
arg2.dc_text: Samuli Virtanen avoided media attention when the situation was most serious, and the risk of leakage about the parliamentarians’ transition was too big

arg3+.text: when the risk of leakage about the parliamentarians’ transition was too big

Chilly-merge.sent: Chilly Gonzales (born Jason Charles Beck; 20 March 1972) is a Grammy-winning Canadian musician who resided in Paris, France for several years, and now lives in Cologne, Germany.
Known for his albums of classical piano compositions with a pop music sensibility, Solo Piano I and Solo Piano II, as well as his MC and electro albums, he is also a producer and songwriter.

arg2.text: his/(Chilly Gonzales's) albums/(Solo Piano I and Solo Piano II) of classical piano compositions with a pop music sensibility
arg2.dc_text: Chilly Gonzales's Solo Piano I and Solo Piano II of classical piano compositions with a pop music sensibility

Chilly-merge.sent: Gonzales broadcasts a web series Pop Music Masterclass on WDR, the documentary Classical Connections on BBC Radio 1, The History of Music on Arte, and Music's Cool with Chilly Gonzales on Apple Music's Beats1 radio show.

arg3+.text: on Apple Music's Beats1 radio show

Chilly-merge.sent: He has written several newspaper and magazine opinion pieces in The Guardian, Vice, Billboard, and others.
He is the younger brother of the prolific film composer Christophe Beck.
His parents are Ashkenazi Jews who had to flee from Hungary during World War II.
Gonzales began teaching himself piano at age three, when his older brother Chris began taking lessons.
Gonzales graduated from Crescent School in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
He was classically trained as a pianist at McGill University, where he began both his composing career, co-authoring several musicals with his brother, and his performing career, as a jazz virtuoso.

EmAlgo-merge.sent: In statistics, an expectation–maximization (EM) algorithm is an iterative method to find maximum likelihood or maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimates of parameters in statistical models, where the model depends on unobserved latent variables.

arg2.text: an iterative method to find maximum likelihood or maximum a posteriori estimates of parameters in statistical models
arg2.dc_text: an iterative method to find maximum likelihood or maximum a posteriori estimates of parameters in statistical models

arg2.text: maximum likelihood estimates of parameters in statistical models
arg2.dc_text: maximum likelihood estimates of parameters in statistical models

arg2.text: maximum a posteriori estimates of parameters in statistical models
arg2.dc_text: maximum a posteriori estimates of parameters in statistical models

EmAlgo-merge.sent: The EM iteration alternates between performing an expectation (E) step, which creates a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood evaluated using the current estimate for the parameters, and a maximization (M) step, which computes parameters maximizing the expected log-likelihood found on the E step.

arg2.text: performing an expectation step and a maximization step
arg2.dc_text: performing an expectation step and a maximization step

arg2.text: a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood
arg2.dc_text: a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood

arg3+.text: using the current estimate for the parameters

arg2.text: parameters maximizing (the expected log-likelihood found on the E step)/(a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood)
arg2.dc_text: parameters maximizing a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood

arg1.text: a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood
arg1.dc_text: a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood

arg2.text: the current estimate for the parameters
arg2.dc_text: the current estimate for the parameters

arg2.text: (the expected log-likelihood found on the E step)/(a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood)
arg2.dc_text: a function for the expectation of the log-likelihood

EmAlgo-merge.sent: These parameter-estimates are then used to determine the distribution of the latent variables in the next E step.

arg1.text: (These parameter-estimates)/(parameters maximizing the expected log-likelihood found on the E step)
arg1.dc_text: parameters maximizing the expected log-likelihood found on the E step

arg2.text: the distribution of the latent variables
arg2.dc_text: the distribution of the latent variables

EmAlgo-merge.sent: The EM algorithm was explained and given its name in a classic 1977 paper by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin.

arg2.text: (a classic 1977 paper by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin)/(The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper)

arg3+.text: by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin

arg1.text: (a classic 1977 paper by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin)/(The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper)

arg2.text: (a classic 1977 paper by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin)/(The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper)

arg3+.text: by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin
by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin

arg1.text: (a classic 1977 paper by Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin)/(The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper)
Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin
arg1.dc_text: Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin

EmAlgo-merge.sent: They pointed out that the method had been "proposed many times in special circumstances" by earlier authors.

arg1.text: They/(Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin)
arg1.dc_text: Arthur Dempster, Nan Laird, and Donald Rubin

arg2.text: (the method)/(The EM algorithm) had been "proposed many times in special circumstances" by earlier authors
arg2.dc_text: The EM algorithm had been "proposed many times in special circumstances" by earlier authors

EmAlgo-merge.sent: A very detailed treatment of the EM method for exponential families was published by Rolf Sundberg in his thesis and several papers following his collaboration with Per Martin-Löf and Anders Martin-Löf.

arg1.text: A treatment of (the EM method)/(The EM algorithm) for exponential families
arg1.dc_text: A treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

arg1.text: A very detailed treatment of (the EM method)/(The EM algorithm) for exponential families

arg1.text: A treatment of (the EM method)/(The EM algorithm) for exponential families
arg1.dc_text: A treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

arg1.dc_text: A very detailed treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

arg2.dc_text: A treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

arg2.text: A treatment of (the EM method)/(The EM algorithm) for exponential families
arg2.dc_text: A treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

arg2.text: A very detailed treatment of (the EM method)/(The EM algorithm) for exponential families
arg2.dc_text: A very detailed treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

arg2.dc_text: A very detailed treatment of The EM algorithm for exponential families

EmAlgo-merge.sent: The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper in 1977 generalized the method and sketched a convergence analysis for a wider class of problems.

arg3+.text: for a wider class of problems

EmAlgo-merge.sent: Regardless of earlier inventions, the innovative Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper in the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society received an enthusiastic discussion at the Royal Statistical Society meeting with Sundberg calling the paper "brilliant".

arg1.text: (the innovative Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper in the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society)/(The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper)

arg3+.text: at the Royal Statistical Society meeting

arg2.text: the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society
arg2.dc_text: the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society

EmAlgo-merge.sent: The Dempster–Laird–Rubin paper established the EM method as an important tool of statistical analysis.

arg3+.text: as an important tool of statistical analysis

arg2.text: an important tool of statistical analysis
arg2.dc_text: an important tool of statistical analysis

Central-merge.sent: After a year of relatively healthy global economic growth, economists are predicting pretty much the same for 2018 -- a neither too-hot nor too-cold Goldilocks scenario, but with little sight of the three bears.

arg2.text: a neither too-hot nor too-cold Goldilocks scenario
arg2.dc_text: a neither too-hot nor too-cold Goldilocks scenario

arg2.text: a neither too-hot nor too-cold Goldilocks scenario
arg2.dc_text: a neither too-hot nor too-cold Goldilocks scenario

Central-merge.sent: The idea is that all is pretty much on track for growth that will be stronger than in 2017.

arg2.text: all is pretty much on track for growth that will be stronger than in 2017
arg2.dc_text: all is pretty much on track for growth that will be stronger than in 2017

arg2.text: growth that will be stronger than in 2017
arg2.dc_text: growth that will be stronger than in 2017

Central-merge.sent: Part of this may come from the fact that forecasters generally got it wrong last year, underclubbing this year’s economic performance, particularly for the euro zone and Japan.

arg2.text: the fact that forecasters got it wrong last year
arg2.dc_text: the fact that forecasters got it wrong last year

Central-merge.sent: The International Monetary Fund, for example, saw 2017 global growth at 3.4 percent with advanced economies advancing 1.8 percent.
It now reckons them at 3.6 percent and 2.2 percent.
It had the euro zone and Japan growing 1.5 percent and 0.6 percent, respectively.
It now has them at 2.1 percent and 1.5 percent.

arg2.text: them/(the growth rate of the euro zone)
arg2.dc_text: the growth rate of the euro zone

Central-merge.sent: “Faster growth is reaching roughly two-thirds of the world’s population,” the IMF said in a December blog post.

arg2.text: “Faster growth is reaching roughly two-thirds of the world’s population,”
arg2.dc_text: “Faster growth is reaching roughly two-thirds of the world’s population,”

Central-merge.sent: This performance has made some economists optimistic.
Nomura is among the more bullish: “Global growth has far more self-reinforcing characteristics at present than at any time over the last 20-30 years.”

arg2.text: “Global growth has far more self-reinforcing characteristics at present than  at any time over the last 20-30 years.”
arg2.dc_text: “Global growth has far more self-reinforcing characteristics at present than  at any time over the last 20-30 years.”

arg3+.text: than at any time over the last 20-30 years

Central-merge.sent: But Goldilock’s bears do have a habit of showing up.
There are huge numbers of potential political and economic risks to the status quo.

arg1.text: risks to (the status quo)/(a year of relatively healthy global economic growth)
arg1.dc_text: risks to a year of relatively healthy global economic growth

arg2.text: (the status quo)/(a year of relatively healthy global economic growth)
arg2.dc_text: a year of relatively healthy global economic growth

arg2.text: (the status quo)/(a year of relatively healthy global economic growth)
arg2.dc_text: a year of relatively healthy global economic growth

arg2.text: (the status quo)/(a year of relatively healthy global economic growth)
arg2.dc_text: a year of relatively healthy global economic growth

Central-merge.sent: But as in the fairy tale, let’s go with just three: central banks, trade, and bubbles.

arg2.text: [a year of relatively healthy global economic growth]
arg2.dc_text: [a year of relatively healthy global economic growth]

arg2.text: [a year of relatively healthy global economic growth]

arg2.text: [a year of relatively healthy global economic growth]
arg2.dc_text: [a year of relatively healthy global economic growth]

Central-merge.sent: In the first case, the danger is that there will be a policy mistake, squeezing debtors.

arg1.text: (the danger)/(the danger to a year of relatively healthy global economic growth)
arg1.dc_text: the danger to a year of relatively healthy global economic growth

arg2.text: there will be a policy mistake
arg2.dc_text: there will be a policy mistake

arg1.text: (a policy mistake)/(a policy mistake [by central banks])

Central-merge.sent: The second relates to renewed U.S. protectionism or anger over Chinese exports triggering tit-for-tat, growth-stifling trade barriers.

arg1.dc_text: The second danger to a year of relatively healthy global economic growth
